topics.body:
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5595ac6a6368723ecb001261#post_5595ac6a6368723ecb001261
What's funny is now thanks to anime introducing the idea of beneficial parasites hardening the body and such there's actual plot justification for characters wearing skimpy clothing.

"Why is that person almost naked?"
"Cause there's a beneficial parasite living inside them that hardens in response to damage"
"Well why aren't they wearing clothes?"
"Cause clothing isn't fire proof"
"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5595ad6a6368727f9a0019f8#post_5595ad6a6368727f9a0019f8
It's meh; not bad, but not good.

Story summary: military contractor creates parasites that transform human bodies into weaponry by cloning the original parasite, but the parasite clones need human hosts to function.

topics.body: If I have to say one nice things about the Witchblade anime, it's that the intro song XTC was fucking rad.
topics.author: 4fde4618945b700aa0002fff

topics.body:
This might be a bit of heresy, but I'm actually kind of excited how more anime are having cgi in it.
*dodges sniper fire*
Cgi in anime isn't necessarily a bad thing; it's just hard to pull off successfully cause the majority of the people working on anime have never touched 3d modeling or animating in their lives and their boss comes in one day and goes "You're going to learn how to make 3d models and animate them within the month!  Okay?  Bye!"

When it's done well it's almost completely unnoticeable and cuts down on costs.  When it's done poorly it sticks out like a sore thumb.

Nowadays a lot of anime does to some level have cgi in it and most of the time it's unnoticeable cause the new people coming into the anime industry are at least familiar with cgi and for the most part use it on things you wouldn't really give a shit about.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5595b3f4636872628700003e#post_5595b3f4636872628700003e

topics.body:

For once, at least in terms of anime, you and I are in total agreement. And considering the schedule a lot of professional animators are on most of them don't have the time to take proper classes to lear 3D modelling. So they pretty much have to learn on the job.

It's not really any different than western cartoons using it. Have you tried animating a train? Doing a simplified guy can be hard enough. Just making a cartoon shaded cg model saves alot of work.
